Award.AwardTitle: Designing Dual Licensure Programs for STEM Majors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Capacity Building project is laying the foundation for the creation of four specialized dual licensure programs to help meet the needs of rural and high-needs school districts for qualified secondary school teachers with one of four pairs of high demand specialties: mathematics and physics, life sciences and chemistry, mathematics and teaching of English as a Second Language (TESL), and life sciences and TESL. The PIs are coordinating a team of five content and education faculty, science and mathematics representatives from community college partners, and colleagues from high-needs school districts, to work together to design the new licensure programs, prepare institutional and state approval applications, and establish articulation agreements. Primary expected outcomes include: 1) the establishment of strong partnerships between the PI's institution, three two-year institutions, a regional service cooperative, and a number of local high need school districts; 2) the development and piloting of a targeted recruitment plan to engage STEM majors in considering a career in teaching, and 3) the design of mentoring, administration, and evaluation plans to support full-fledged implementation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
School districts in northwestern Minnesota have a shortage of highly qualified secondary science and math teachers. High need districts in both urban and select rural communities have an increasing need for science or math teachers who also have expertise teaching English Language Learners. The primary goal of this capacity building proposal was to develop and pilot programs and partnerships to recruit and mentor talented math and science majors to encourage them to consider a career in teaching.

Notable outcomes of this planning effort include 1) the establishment of strong partnerships between the grant recipient university, a regional service cooperative, and a number of local high need school districts to determine local math and science teacher needs, 2) the piloting and development of a science and math major recruitment plan to consider teaching, and 3) the design of mentoring, administration, and evaluation plans to support the submission of a Noyce Phase I Scholarship proposal to provide scholarships for science and math majors to become licensed teachers. A five-year, $1.1 million scholarship grant was awarded beginning in December 2015, with the majority of the funds going towards scholarships to support the education of at least 35 new math and science teachers.

A team of math and science content and education faculty worked together to put together the scholarship proposal. The principal investigators served as the partnership liaisons and facilitated partner interactions, in addition to creating the administration and evaluation plans. The recruiting liaison worked with faculty STEM club advisors and outreach coordinators to design a recruiting plan to attract science and math majors to the education field. The mentoring liaison worked with partners, including local high need school districts, to design an effective mentoring plan to ensure future scholarship recipients have the support they will need to teach successfully in a high needs school district upon graduation. The program evaluator interacted with the participants through interviews and focus groups to ensure that the objectives have been reached in a timely fashion, and that the licensure programs and the recruiting, mentoring, administration, and evaluation plans demonstrate the desired level of effectiveness and compliance with the Noyce Phase I scholarship grant requirements.

This team is well-equipped to recognize and respond to changing demographics, enrollments, and local financial challenges that require regional school districts to become more creative in the their choice of new hires in order to maximize their chances for effective, highly qualified teachers in areas of highest need. The proposed licensure programs that combine coursework and field experiences in ESL will produce more skilled teachers able to respond to the current and growing needs of our K-12 student populations in high need schools.

This capacity building effort resulted in the development of a system of people, programs, and institutions that will work together to increase STEM teacher capacity by producing flexible and effective science and math teachers who are able and willing to teach in high need school districts and to work with English Language Learners. Ultimately, these efforts will benefit K-12 students by ensuring they have highly qualified math and science teachers equipped to serve the changing demographics of our schools.
